TEXT: The applicants , PERSON , PERSON , PERSON , PERSON and Mr PERSON are NORP citizens , who were born in DATE , respectively and live in GPE , GPE , PERSON , NORP and ORG . They are represented before the ORG by ORG and ORG , lawyers practising in GPE , GPE .
The applicant and her husband lived in GPE . The husband received his pension until DATE when the payments stopped . GPE is situated in a part of GPE which was occupied from DATE until DATE .
In DATE the applicant and her husband left GPE , due to the military operation “ Storm ” ( PERSON ) , and went to live in GPE .
On DATE the husband died .
In DATE the applicant returned to GPE .

It appears that the applicant requested ORG to grant her payments related to her late husband ’s pension . The applicant ’s right to a family pension was recognised as from DATE and the applicant has continued to receive payments of her pension from that date .
The applicant then filed an action with ORG ( PERSON u ORG ) seeking payments of her late husband ’s pension for the period DATE and DATE .

On DATE the court rejected the applicant ’s claim . It found that the applicant and her husband had lived in an occupied part of GPE and that the husband had received a pension from the authorities which controlled that territory . According to LAW a person was allowed to receive CARDINAL pension and since the applicant ’s husband had received a pension from the authorities of the occupied territory he had no right to another pension from the NORP authorities .
On DATE the applicant appealed against the first instance judgment .
On DATE ORG ( PERSON u ORG ) upheld the first instance judgment .
The applicant lived in ORG . She received a family pension until DATE when the payments stopped . ORG is situated in a part of GPE which was occupied from DATE until DATE .
In DATE the applicant left GPE , due to the military operation “ Storm ” , and went to live in GPE .
In DATE the applicant returned to GPE .

It appears that the applicant requested ORG to provide her with a pension . The applicant ’s right to a family pension was recognised as from DATE and the applicant has continued to receive payments of her pension from that date .
The applicant then filed an action with ORG seeking payments of her pension for the period DATE and DATE .

On DATE the court rejected the applicant ’s claim . It found that the applicant had lived in an occupied part of GPE and that she had received a pension from the authorities which controlled that territory . According to LAW a person was allowed to receive CARDINAL pension and since the applicant had received a pension from the authorities of the occupied territory she had no right to another pension from the NORP authorities .
On DATE the applicant appealed against the first instance judgment .
On DATE ORG upheld the first instance judgment .
The applicant lived in GPE . She received a pension until DATE when the payments stopped . Mađari is situated in a part of GPE which was occupied from DATE until DATE .
In DATE the applicant left GPE , due to the military operation “ Storm ” , and went to live in GPE .
In DATE the applicant returned to GPE .

It appears that the applicant requested ORG to pay her pension . The applicant ’s right to a family pension was recognised as from DATE and the applicant has continued to receive payments of her pension from that date .
The applicant then filed an action with ORG seeking payments of her pension for the period DATE and DATE .

On DATE the court rejected the applicant ’s claim . It found that , according to LAW of LAW , it was possible to seek pension instalments only for DATE . Since it was established that the applicant had received a pension for DATE before she had filed her claim with ORG , the period for which the applicant had sought the pension instalments fell within the statutory limitation .
On DATE the applicant appealed against the first instance judgment .
On DATE ORG upheld the first instance judgment .

The applicant lived in NORP . She received a pension until DATE when the payments stopped and the applicant left GPE and went to live in GPE until DATE . Then she returned to GPE and settled in ORG , a town situated in a part of GPE which was occupied from DATE until DATE .
In DATE the applicant left GPE , due to the military operation “ Storm ” , and went to live in GPE .
In DATE the applicant returned to GPE .

It appears that the applicant filed a request for payment of her pension . The applicant ’s right to a family pension was recognised as from DATE and the applicant has continued to receive payments of her pension from that date on .
The applicant then filed an action with ORG seeking payments of her pension for the period DATE and DATE .

On DATE the court rejected the applicant ’s claim . It found that , according to LAW of LAW , it was possible to seek pension instalments only for DATE . Since it was established that the applicant had received a pension for DATE before she had filed her claim with ORG , the period for which the applicant had sought payments of her pension fell within the statutory limitation .
On DATE the applicant appealed against the first instance judgment .
On DATE ORG upheld the first instance judgment .
The applicant lived in ORG . He received a pension until DATE when the payments stopped . ORG is situated in a part of GPE which was occupied from DATE until DATE .
In DATE the applicant left GPE , due to the military operation “ Storm ” , and went to live in GPE .
On DATE the applicant returned to GPE .

It appears that the applicant filed a request for payment of his pension for the period DATE and DATE with ORG , ORG ( Hrvatski zavod za mirovinsko osiguranje , Područna služba u ORG ) . On DATE that authority issued a decision stating that payment of the applicant ’s pension had been stopped on CARDINAL DATE due to the war in GPE . Since the applicant had lived in the occupied territory the NORP authorities had been unable to verify his address . It also stated that the applicant had received a pension from the authorities that had controlled that territory . The applicant ’s right to receive again the payments of his pension from the NORP authorities was recognised as from DATE .
The applicant then filed an action with ORG seeking payments of his pension for the period DATE and DATE .

On DATE the court rejected the applicant ’s claim . It noted that ORG , ORG had decided that the applicant had had no right to a pension for the period in question and found that a regular civil court had no competence to set aside such a decision issued by an administrative body , but only to determine the applicant ’s civil claim for payment . However , such a claim had no legal ground as the applicant ’s right to receive a pension in the period from DATE until DATE had not been recognised by the competent authority .
On DATE the applicant appealed against the first instance judgment .
On DATE ORG upheld the first instance judgment .

On DATE all CARDINAL applicants filed together a constitutional complaint . They recalled that they had requested payment of the pension instalments for the respective periods during which no pension had been paid and alleged that ORG refused to pay , contrary to the law . Thus , their right to the peaceful enjoyment of their property had been violated .

Furthermore , they alleged that their right to equality before the courts was violated because in other proceedings concerning similar claims , other courts in GPE had granted such claims . Also , the exact amount of the pension instalments that they claimed had never been established .
They argued furthermore that the lower courts had erred in the application of laws because they had applied LAW retroactively and also wrongly interpreted the rules regulating statutory limitation .
In respect of the first CARDINAL applicants ORG rejected the complaint on DATE and in respect of the fifth applicant the complaint was rejected on DATE .

It found that , in essence , the constitutional complaint was of a fourth instance nature since the applicants complained that the lower courts wrongly established the facts and erred in their application of the laws . It concluded that the lower courts’ decisions were based on law and well reasoned and that the rights complained of were not violated .
In respect of the first applicant , PERSON ORG stated as follows :
... The applicant is treating her constitutional complaint as a regular legal remedy and is asking ORG to act as a court of appeal in respect of the courts that gave the impugned judgments .

However , according to the constitutional definition of ORG jurisdiction , as regulated by LAW as well as by LAW of LAW , a constitutional complaint is a remedy established for the protection of human rights and fundamental freedoms and may be filed against an act ( and the proceedings that preceded such an act ) that has violated an applicant ’s human rights or fundamental freedoms guaranteed by LAW ( constitutional rights ) .

The applicant asks ORG to rule that the contested judgments violated her rights guaranteed in LAW , LAW , Articles DATE , CARDINAL and DATE , LAW and LAW in connection with ORG , DATE and DATE and LAW .

More specifically , the applicant alleges an infringement of her constitutional rights under LAW and LAW , in that her right to equality before the law and before the courts had been violated because the first - instance court failed to ask the defendant to certify the exact amount of the pension instalments that had not been paid to the applicant during the material period .

However , the first - instance court established that the late applicant ’s husband had received a pension from a “ para - fund ” , whose acts were recognised on the basis of LAW ( Official Gazette no . CARDINAL/CARDINAL ) . According to LAW of the former LAW ( Official Gazette nos . CARDINAL , CARDINAL , CARDINAL , CARDINAL , CARDINAL , CARDINAL , CARDINAL , CARDINAL and CARDINAL ) and LAW of LAW ( Official Gazette no . CARDINAL/CARDINAL ) a beneficiary who has acquired the right to CARDINAL or more pensions is allowed to receive CARDINAL pension . Accordingly , the first - instance court established that the late applicant ’s husband had chosen to receive in the relevant period a pension based on the act that that court recognised pursuant to LAW ; it further established that the applicant had no legal basis to claim for the same period another pension on a different basis .

The applicant herself indicated the value of her claim . In rejecting the applicant ’s request that the exact amount of the pension instalments that she sought be established , having already ruled that her claim had no legal basis , the first - instance court did not violate her right to equality before the law and the courts .

Lastly , the second - instance judgment accepted the defendant ’s objection based on the statutory limitation in LAW , which provides that all outstanding payments under LAW of that provision ( pensions and other monetary instalments ) that have not been paid owing to circumstances caused by a beneficiary can be sought only for DATE when the claim for payment has been filed , noting that the applicant had filed her claim on DATE but had been in receipt of her family pension since DATE , a period of DATE before the time when she filed her claim .

The facts relevant in the proceedings in which the impugned judgments were given , and on which the applicant based her constitutional complaint , are not relevant for the assessment whether the applicant ’s constitutional rights were violated . Presentation of evidence and the establishment of facts fall within the competence of the courts that conducted those proceedings . ”
In respect of the other CARDINAL applicants ORG gave very similar reasoning .

The relevant parts of LAW ( Zakon o mirovinskom osiguranju - ORG no . CARDINAL/CARDINAL ) provide in its LAW that pension instalments which have not been paid owing to circumstances caused by a beneficiary can be sought only for DATE , and that the period before that falls within the statutory limitation .

Section CARDINAL provides that a person who , according to NORP law , is entitled to CARDINAL or more pensions under the compulsory national retirement pension scheme may receive CARDINAL of those pensions .

Section CARDINAL of LAW ( Zakon o konvalidaciji , Official Gazette no . CARDINAL/CARDINAL ) provides that all individual acts and decisions issued by various bodies or legal persons exercising public authority in matters of a judicial or administrative nature in the parts of GPE that were under the protection and authority of ORG , are to be validated by that LAW , according to LAW , LAW on human rights and freedoms and the rights of ethnic and national communities or minorities in GPE and other statutes .
